The primary hazard for storage and handling of formaldehyde solution at this facility is loss of containment resulting in a toxic release.  The "worst case" scenario involves the complete failure of the storage tank with the rapid release of the entire tank contents followed by evaporation.  The storage tank is inside a dike with ten foot high walls to limit the surface area of the liquid pool thereby reducing the evaporation rate.  The release was modeled using the equations found in Appendix D, Section D.2.1 of the Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance.  The "Worst Case" meteorological conditions followed the conditions established in the rule.  The duration of the release was selected as one hour, a temperature of 311?K [100?F] and urban topography were used. The distance to the formaldehyde endpoint is 0.06 miles [317 feet] according to Table 4, Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance.



An alternative release scenario may be the failure of the hose connecting the delivery tank trailer to the unloading transfer pipeline.  This scenario was selected as a more credible failure incident.  The driver unloads the tank trailer under the surveillance of Degussa-Huls security personnel. The release rate of 450 lb./min for three minutes was selected.  The driver must stay with his vehicle during the unloading operation.  The trailer is parked inside the "well" of a nearby loading dock.  Spilled liquid would be trapped inside the "well".  The following conditions were used;  wind speed 3.0 m/s, Class D stability, and urban topography.  A release rate for evaporation was calculated from equation 18, Chapter 8, Section 8.2.3, Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance was used.  A 10 minute duration for the release gave a 0.06 mile (317 feet) distance to the toxic endpoint.





Accidental Release Prevention Program



The prevention program used at the facility is the Occupational Safety and Health Administrations Process Safety Management standard.  The standard

covers management system elements involving safety information, hazard evaluations, operating procedures, employee training, contractor controls, mechanical integrity, pre-startup reviews, incident investigations, safe work practices, and emergency response.



There are a number of specific measures in place to reduce the likelihood of a release of formaldehyde solution or it's impact.  The tank liquid level is monitored by two level gauges.  The two gauges must read within 100 gallons of each other.  Additional material is not ordered until the tank level is at 1500 gallons.  This will allow the total contents of the delivery tank trailer to be safely unloaded into the storage tank.  The storage tank has an installed high level monitor and alarm that alerts the driver if the tank level is too high.



The driver and Degussa-Huls security personnel are on hand throughout the unloading operation and are able to shut down the operation in the event of a leak before a large release has occurred.



The pipe line and storage tank are constructed of welded stainless steel.  This material is compatible with and resistant to corrosion from formaldehyde solution.





Five-year Accident History



There have not been any releases of formaldehyde solution at this facility.





Emergency Response Program



Emergencies at the facility are handled according to the "Emergency Plan"  and details the actions required to respond to plant emergencies such as chemical spills, medical emergencies, fire, gas leaks, bomb threats, explosions and natural disasters.



Decisions regarding the evacuation of personnel and the notification of outside agencies are made by the Emergency Response Management Team chairperson or Vice Chairperson.  If the emergency plan is activated during the second or third shift the Shift Manager will make the notification.  On Saturday the Saturday Manager-in-Charge will make the notification is necessary.



The Hazardous Entry and Abatement Team will resp

ond to chemical spills.  Team members have been trained in response and mitigation techniques.  Team members annual drills.  Their first response is to stop the release and contain the spread of material.  The formaldehyde storage tank is contained inside a dike with walls that are ten feet high.  The tank is further sheltered on three sides by the production building.  The entire contents of the storage tank will be contained inside the dike.



During unloading the tank trailer is parked inside the "well" of the nearby loading dock.  Spills occurring during unloading will be contained inside the "well".





Planned Improvement to the Prevention Program



The prevention program at the facility is the facility is the Process Safety Management System required by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration Standard 1910.119.



The Mechanical Integrity element at the facility is currently undergoing revisions.  The remaining elements will be reviewed for possible updating and improvement later this year following the annual facility maintenance shutdown in the summer.
